headline: Easy Pie Crust
description: This easy pie crust is so simple to make with flour, sugar, salt, oil, and milk. And best of all, you don't need a mixing bowl or rolling pin!

video.description: This crust is so easy, you don’t even need a mixing bowl!
video.name: Easy Pie Crust

name: Easy Pie Crust

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).

Combine flour, oil, milk, sugar, and salt in a 9-inch pie pan; stir with a fork until mixture comes together. Pat into the bottom and up the sides of the pan. Poke holes in the bottom and sides with a fork.
Bake in the preheated oven until light golden brown, about 15 minutes. Use as directed in your favorite pie recipe.

review.reviewBody: I used BEEF TALLOW and butter melted. It works fine! Great easy recipe. Mixed in a bowl first and baked at 350 for 5 minutes and 400 for 5 minutes. Came out great. I stink at pie crust!

Made this for a pumpkin pie and it turned out perfect! Not sure why people are complaining about the salt amount, you can just tweak it or not add it at all. This recipe is perfect and very versatile with other pies.
Averted a disaster with this quick pie crust - it was great who knew! I substitued butter for the oil it was a hit and so easy
This is a shortcrust dough, it doesn't roll, but it's beautiful for pressed pies, quiches. I made a chocolate pie and it was just right.

I used a tin pan, and the mixing made the dough have a metal taste. The bottom was too thick due to poor process. Bottom corner and sides cooked up hard and unchewable. The vegetable oil and salt amounts were too much, and made the pumpkin pie taste like salty oil with hard clumps. Use glass pan, less salt to taste, add some sugar to taste. Flour type make a big difference in crusts. Use pastry flour 00 and traditional crust technique.
Very simple pie crust and turned out very flakey. Slightly sweet too. I would mix the ingredients in a bowl first next time. Too messy directly in the pie pan. Very good.

This was a great recipe for me because I was looking for something without butter! This crust reminded me of shortbread! I used it to make mini strawberry pies so I put in 2 tbsp sugar and 1/4 tsp salt! Came out so tasty I can eat the crust by itself! Definitely will be using this as my go-to pie shell recipe!
I made this recipe yesterday, SUCCESS!!! Thank you!!! So rich and tasty, family raved about it
I'm not sure what I did wrong, but this didn't work for me. It was a crumbly mess. But we just turned our apple pie into an apple crumble!

I made exactly as written. The final result reminded me biting a salty cracker. I don't think I would use this for a dessert pie but it was great for a chicken pot pie. One thing, it did smoke while cooking because of the oil dripping out of the crust, so if you use it as a top crust I would put a pan under it to catch the drippings so they don't burn. But I was really pleasantly surprised at how it transformed during baking. Nice option for when you need a quick crust.
So EASY! I've made it twice now. The first time I used Olive Oil, the second time I used vegetable Oil. Extremely easy, and tastes great!!
Super easy and absolutely amazing once you reduce the salt.
Very easy!
I followed directions to a T. It does not work as a top crust. It crumbles and does not hold together.
I like that it is easy and fast. Some thought it was oily. I used butter and half the amount of salt. . Works perfect every time.
I don't know if I'll make it again but it was okay
suprisingly flaky and very easy to make

I was looking for a fast pie crust and I found it. It was Sunday night and my daughter reminded me that Sunday is dessert day. I had all of the ingredients for a pumpkin pie but not enough time to make a crust. I used this recipe and it was perfect. I always use melted coconut oil when recipes call for vegetable oil. I baked the crust as directed, then added the filling and baked according to the pumpkin pie recipe. It was delicious! I disagree with other reviewers who said it was too salty and not sweet enough for a dessert pie. You need a bit of salt to balance out the sweet.

Fabulous! Super easy. You really CAN just mix this with a fork right in the pie plate, mold it and you’re good to go. Loved the flakiness and taste. Like other reviewers, I added only a pinch of salt and increased the sugar just a bit for a sweet pie. Never, ever buying a pie crust again.
this is good but I wouldn't recommend doing a double crust pie wit it.

Followed other reviewers instructions to reduce salt and increase sugar for a fruit pie. Dough was hard to work with when making top layer. Wasn’t able to get crust as thin as I’d like without it crumbling apart. I didn’t mind the flavour or thicker crust, but Hubby said he didn’t like it, all he could taste was flour and it seemed like something was missing (probably the buttery flavour he’s used to).
i love it
This is the best tasting pie crust I have ever tasted. Simple and delicious.
It was easy, it came out flaky, but it did not taste great at all! It tasted like oil. I'm going to try it with melted butter next time.
This was so easy and came out much better than I thought for something so simple with no butter. Thank you! I will use this again.
Easy peasy. I made an apple pie with crumb top! Fastest pie ever made....now the ice cream!

I subbed coconut oil for the vegetable oil which worked great. It left a subtle coconut flavor...perfect for my strawberry rhubarb pie. I also left out the salt. Solid recipe. I love that it’s just a few ingredients.
Love this. Only change - reduced the salt to about 3/4 tsp. and I increased the milk to about 1/4 cup.
The recipe worked as described for the sweet potato pie I made. I will use it again.
Great recipe. If making a pecan pie, use a glass pie pan. It comes out much better.
This is the easiest pie crust ever! It was tasty, light and fluffy. I'm using it again right now for another pumpkin pie. Perfect!
Good don't use as much salt maybe half

Wanted to make my husband a banana cream pie but didn’t want to spend a whole lot of time on the crust. I found this, read the reviews and gave it a whirl. I doubled the recipe on everything except the salt so I could have an extra crust. I blended the milk and oil together before putting it into the dry ingredients I had already mixed into a bowl. I used a pastry cutter and it came out awesome, not too salty at all. Glad I doubled the recipe so ready for my coconut cream,????
Easy. Made with on hand ingredients. A no fail recipe, even for someone who doesn’t usually make pie crust.

I loved this pie crust recipe. It was quick and easy to make. I am a novice pie crust maker, baker and cook. I just had a small suggestion. I have a 9" deep dish Pyrex glass pie dish. I found that 1-1/2 cups of flour didn't quite cover my pie dish. The next time I make this pie crust I will use 2 cups of flour and adjust other ingredients to cover my only pie crust dish. I didn't prebake this crust. I just added my pumpkin filling. The pie crust was flaky and delicious. Thanks for this recipe. I now feel confident enough to make my own pie crusts and not use the store bought crusts.

sooooo easy and good taste 
I used 1/2cup whole wheat flour and it works well. It tastes much crispier.

I needed a crust for a pie recipe I found on another website (that one used store-bought).

I followed the reviews and added more sugar (~ 1/4 cup). It turned out well. The edges were a bit hard.

I like that the recipe is easy, and the crust can be made quickly.
This is my go to pie crust. It's simple and tastes wonderful as it is lightly savory.
This crust is so good and easy to make!
I used 1/2 cup of plain flour and 1 cup of whole meal and just a pinch of salt. Crispy as hoped and cuts well!

This pie crust is definitely NOT flaky and does have a strong oily taste. It is easy, but so are better pie crust recipes. This kind of reminds me of the density of graham cracker crusts without the flavour. If you do choose to make this crust, it is definitely NOT good for sweets. It might work for meat pies, but I think any other pie crust that uses butter or shortening would be better than this oil recipe. Thanks anyway

So i didn't have regular vegetable oil and substituted coconut oil. I don't know if this was the reason I found the crust hard to handle/ manage but it definitely could have contributed. I felt it was extremely sticky and when I made the top crust for my pie it was falling all apart so I had to lay it on strips.
This is a great quick and easy crust recipe. I use it when I make chicken pot pie or tomato pie. It is flaky and perfect!

Five stats for being so fast and easy!
I followed the advice of others and cut the salt to a pinch since I was using this for a fruit tart, and I used coconut oil -- it was very good & so, so easy!

I was making a wild blackberry pie and took into account previous reviewers' remarks. I decreased the salt to a pinch and used 1 Tablespoon sugar. The pie was phenomenal! This recipe is a keeper. 
P.S.forgot to mention that I also substituted whole wheat pastry flour for the white flour.

YES YES YES. I've been looking for this! I made it exactly as is, rolled it out partially but not too thin so I could pick it up and put it in my pie dish. Then I used my fingers to spread the dough out and up the sides of the dish. I saw a tip to roll it out on waxed paper and then place it in the greased pie dish and peel off the wax-- I'll try that next time! I used this for a quiche, but I understand that if used for a pie it would need more sugar added. This worked perfect and it was easy. No more refrigerated Pillsbury pie dough needed anymore. Woo hooo!

First attempt at crust from scratch! Followed reviewers suggestion to use less salt and more sugar if using for sweet instead of savory dish. I ended up adding about 2 tablespoons more flour after I pressed crust into pan because it felt too greasy. Turned out really well though. Every one loved the chocolate pudding pie I made with it. My mom said it was great, and she wonders now if she prefers a pressed crust instead of rolled because of the texture. It held well during serving, and was kinda flaky or crumbly when eating (yummy). Will definitely make it again and try as written for a savory dish!
This is soooooo easy to make! I used gluten free flour which can be tough to work with, so this recipe is perfect for that. I've made this 5 times now and it's perfect every time.
Good for every recipe I could think of. THANKS SO MUCH. Although I use 1/3 cup oil.works for me!

I was pleasantly surprised w this crust!! The dough looks oily but it bakes up nicely, flakey and tender. I've used it twice- as written- for quiche. No need to prebake. It held up well in the fridge for a few days- no soggy. Today I used this for a pudding pie. As recommended I used 3T sugar and 1/2 the salt, also added a splash of vanilla, an yes, I baked this one 13 min. Tastes like shortbread.
no changes at all, and yes will make it again! My husband never eats 2 crust pies as he is diabetic so this works just great for pumpkin pie ( and quiches too!)

It was not a family favorite. I liked the idea of it being easy... and it was. But it came out more like a powdery texture graham crust. Not the crust for a quiche. It may work perfect for a different type of pie.
Perfect for 9" pie plate, not enough yield for a 9.5".

A big hit on Thanksgiving as crust for Grandma Ople's Apple Pie. As other reviewers noted, I changed to 1T of sugar and reduced salt. I made a second one and tried to roll it for a lattice topping- that didn't work as far as looks but the taste was great. Altogether a great option for a baked from scratch pie in a short time. And at Thanksgiving, who has extra time?
This is great. It gets 5 stars when the salt is cut in half.

Going to call this "my in a pinch pie crust ". Needed a pie crust in a hurry so thought I'd give it a try.Was skeptical at first but when I saw the end result I was surprised at how easy and good it was. My grandson who is the pie expert said it was the best pie ever. I will definitely will make it again.

I followed the recipe except I used less salt and a little more sugar after reading some reviews. This was the most horrible, greasy crust we have ever eaten , and I would never waste my time making it again .

I made this crust for a deep dish peach pie. I did cut the salt by half and increased the sugar by 1 tbspn. Swapped vegetable for coconut oil and used almond milk. It was flaky and cut beautifully. I'll post the next pie, because this one was devoured.

Thank you for sharing this awesome and super- easy recipe! I've made two flawless fruit (cherry & blackberry) pies with perfect crumble. I double the recipe, add twice the amount of sugar, divide it for the bottom crust, then add either a touch more sugar or cinnamon for the crumble. The topping turns out crisp and beautifully brown. I've had no issue with the bottom being soggy, even without egg wash. I do think pre-baking the crust is key. A keeper!!
Pie crust was Easy to make but once cooked was gross flavorless
Easy to make but very dry, crumbly sandy texture
The pie crust was not a pie crust. It turned out as a crumbly mess. It didn't cook and when it did it cooked very quickly and burnt. I would not recommend making this pie crust.
love this its so flaky just the way it should be

Okay pie crust. Does not work for a double crust, so only use if you need bottom crust. Very quick and easy, and for that I gave it 3 stars. Not as flaky as a typical pie crust recipe, obviously but not awful.

I used olive oil as others said using veg oil changed the taste and it wasn't good. With olive oil it tasted great. Found it to be a bit crumbly so added milk as I patted into dish and it came together well. If using it for dessert add more sugar. Great starter easy pie crust to make

This was an easy recipe to make...I mixed it all in my kitchen aide and put in the pie plate and spread out then. I added half the salt and a bit more sugar to the recipe. I did use organic raw sugar, unbleached flour and olive oil instead. My family loved the crust with our chocolate pie...it was flaky but held together nicely!! Will make again.

I have made this many times. My only complaint is it is so crumbly. You can't roll it out like most pie crusts. It is super easy though. This last time I added 1 egg to it and it seemed like it held together a bit more than without. It is perfect for pot pies with the salt, but for fruit and cream pies I half the salt. It has a very good flavor. I gave it 4 which is an average of 3 (crumbly texture ) and 5 (flavor and ease)
Great taste, easy to do, and mixed all in the pan!

I made a peach pie with this recipe but I had no vegetable oil so I used melted margarine and found myself using 4 more TBS melted margarine AMD 4 more TBS milk but worked out great, tasted perfect with the peach filling my sisters loved it.

Replacing 1/2 of oil with soften, unsalted butter, add a touch of Cardamom and Nutmeg and cut back on Salt - that would be 5 stars! Easily the best, easiest, crumbly and light weight crust for Euro style thin tarts. Last made for Cranberry Custard tart, exceptional base!

Replacing 1/2 of oil with soften, unsalted butter, add a touch of Cardamom and Nutmeg and cut back on Salt - that would be 5 stars! Easily the best, easiest, crumbly and light weight crust for Euro style thin tarts. Last made for Cranberry Custard tart, exceptional base!

It was great to try this recipe, which is simpler and i made it for vanilla cream pie, i didn't add that much salt and i added milk a lil bit more, i used brown sugar instead of white one, and avocado oil. It was great, even if it's a little bit tougher (positively we can say it crunchy! :D) but my friend said it was yummy and the crust wasn't fleaky indeed but still yummy :) Thanks for sharing!

If I could give this ZERO stars, I would have..
It was grainy, fell apart, greasy and a waste of resources and labor intensive.
Was very easy to make! I would give it 5 stars except I have yet to eat it as the pie is cooling. Im sure it will taste gopd though, I added extra sugar with some cinnamon in my crust.

This was a perfect pie crust for a pumpkin pie! This year I was single-handedly cooking a Thanksgiving meal for 17 people, and I tried to "cheat" and use a store-bought graham cracker crust for my pumpkin pie. That crust fell apart the second I opened it, and with no time to go to the store, I had to find an emergency recipe with ingredients I already had in my kitchen! This was perfect for what I needed it for. I followed a tip from another reviewer and modified it to 1 tablespoon of sugar, and 1/2 teaspoon of salt. It was great. However, it would be impossible to use if you need to put a top layer of crust on your pie.
Way too much salt! Ruined my lemon meringue pie. Will not be making it again.

I needed to make a pumpkin pie for Thanksgiving and my local Harris Teeter stopped carrying Immaculate Pie Crusts. Those are the only ones that I've found without animal lard (ugh). So I found this recipe and it was a hit for Thanksgiving dinner. I loved it as well. It's super easy and very tasty. I'll use this again and again. In the past, I never wanted to tackle a homemade pie crust.

You just saved me! I had no idea how easy it could be to make pie crust. I was feeling lazy and didn't want to deal with the roller etc. I followed the recipe but made it in a bowl first with the fork, then once incorporated transferred it to the pan. Easy and perfect! I made a quiche so I didn't cook the crust first and it cooked perfectly. Thanks again!
Best pie crust ever!!! Easiest too!
The only thing I didn't make from scratch was pie crust. That ended when I found this recipe. I add a little cinnamon and my sweet potato pie was DELICIOUS. I'll never buy frozen crust again.

It's not a flaky pie crust but l love how EASY it is to make. It is quick way to make a pie and taste GREAT.
LOVED IT!!!!!!!!
Don't mean to be rude but I don't know why others had so much trouble. Also the recipe said mix all ingredients in the pan (And nothing about rolling it out).
I was able to roll out a top crust. I just had to keep drying and flouring the rolling pin then I cut it in half to get it on the pie and it came out Great!
My first time ever making pie crust. I used it in a chicken pot pie recipe. Very easy to make, but a little salty. I think next time I will cut the salt in half.
so easy and tasty
perfect as written for chicken pot pie!

I used gluten-free all-purpose flour mix (Bob's Red Mill). And this was FANTASTIC! It turned out like a shortbread crust, a little crumbly and flaky...PERFECT DESSERT CRUST! or for any type of pie, for that matter!

The crust turned out crumbly and sandy with a greasy off taste. If you're really tight on time and/or ingredients, I think it would be fine in a strong tasting pie, like a fruit pie or a pot pie or something. I used it for a light egg custard pie, and the weird crust taste was very prominent. The only change I made to the recipe was to decrease the salt to 1/2 tsp since I was making a sweet pie.
I wont ever use this recipe again. It was grainy and had a sandy feel to it. It is also very dry and fell apart.
Just made this...amazingly great crust. The mess that traditional crust makes had me buying crust, no more! So easy and flaky; isn't that what we all want?
Good. Definitely a lot of salt, so I reduced by half and added some sugar. Very simple to make.

Great recipe, one thing I liked better is substituting Cocoanut milk and then reducing the salt to half teaspoon and reducing the sugar to one teaspoon. Bake ahead of filling with fruit for ten minutes. After filling with fruit or quiche recipe, bake again as suggested. Worked great for my strawberry/apple pie! Thanks.

I agree with other comments, there are better crusts out there. But I am going to keep this recipe as well, because of course they are not made with oil, and this is definitely a plus! moreover, it is not messy at all: if you really want to keep it to a minimum effort, you don't need a bowl and a rolling pin either. I mean to try it again, making the kitchen robot do all the work; I think it will be more "smooth" and perhaps less sandy and grainy... also, if you plan to use this for a sweet pie, be careful of the amount of salt (I happened to use it on my first try with a caramel filling, and it was fortunate, I declared that I had a "caramel au burre salè" French pie in mind from the beginning, but it was so untrue!

Definitely easy to make. I was using it for a pumpkin pie, and so I followed other user suggestions and cut the salt and upped the sugar. HOWEVER, I still had the taste of vegetable oil in my mouth for five minutes after finishing my slice of pie. If you're using it for something sweet, I would definitely suggest using melted butter as your lipid instead. It would make for a much more savory, less gross aftertasting dessert.
This is easy and quick and tastes a whole lot better than the store bought crust!!
Everyone else loved this but I wasn't so fond. Made it with a quiche, and that would be all I would use it with.
Easy for sure. Mine came out extremely crumbly and it's missing that buttery flaky component that's found in traditional crust.
This is a good recipe but way to much salt, I decreased the salt to 1/4 tsp and added a 1/2 tsp vanilla to give the crust a richer flavor.

I just made this for Chicken pot pie it tastes good it smells good but when I was making the top layer for the chicken pot pie I couldn't handle the piecrust. It literally fell apart it would not stay together had to piece it together on top of the chicken pot pie. If you're using this crust for just the bottom then I would say yes it's good but if you're needing this crust to use as a top layer for any dish I would say absolutely not.
This is disgusting! I followed instructions and baked for over 45 minutes and it NEVER fully cooked. Ruined my entire steak and cheese pie. Take this down!
I cant roll the crust
